text: I was actually taken just an hour after
we filmed that video that you just
watched we were driving through a number
of checkpoints and on the last
checkpoint before our hotel in slavyansk
some armed men who had my picture
recognized me and pulled me and some of
my colleagues out of the car and that's
how my detention began we were taken to
the SBU Security Services Building
that's been taken over by pro-russian
gunmen now and I was separated from my
other colleagues and taken down into the
basement blindfolded I had my hands tied
behind my back
and I was thrown on the floor and beaten
up and then held there for the next
three days did these men who took you
say who they were some of them were very
clearly locals from slavyansk my sort of
caretakers the people who brought me
food and there was a sort of mother a
salon of gunmen who were also seemed to
be local in terms of being from the same
city they were kind of more ragtag and
then there were those guys who we called
the Special Ops guys and they looked a
lot more professional had more modern
guns and uniforms that matched and they
could very well have been from Ukraine
and I I wasn't able to get any evidence
from those guys in particular that they
came from Russia they sounded like they
had southern accents to me so they could
have been from Ukraine or southern
Russia but I think that there are a lot
of local Ukrainians involved in this
pro-russia uprising but you know as I
showed in the other video there are
definitely Russian citizens down there
as well
why did they release you it's hard for
me to say but I think maybe the
self-declared mayor of slovyansk who I
think is the person calling the shots
and who ordered my release was
eventually tired of all of the pressure
that he was getting
from journalists asking after me I think
the problem though now is that there are
local journalists and just other
activists Ukrainian people who are still
being held by him for no apparent reason
and there's not been a lot of attention
put on their cases because they're not
foreign and they've been down in that
same cellar that I spent three days and
four weeks now and I think that there
should be a lot more attention brought
brought to their cases did you see any
evidence of any kind that the Russian
state was involved in what was going on
there in the place where I was actually
being held I was blindfolded the entire
time and when I was being interrogated I
wasn't ever allowed to look at the faces
of the people interrogating me so I
wasn't asking them for their business
cards either so I I don't know whether
they were weren't from Russia I can't
say for sure did you get any evidence
that they were organized as opposed to
being some group of II regulars they
were a group of irregular who were
organized in my view I think they
communicate with the other pro-russia
cities that have been well the
pro-russian forces that have taken over
administration buildings and in other
parts of Ukraine and I think they're
pretty coordinated in what they're doing
